questions.text: A new-born baby with single palmar crease and coarse facies. On further evaluation, baby had atrial septal defect. During the karyotyping, Down Syndrome was diagnosed. What is the primary genetic mechanism responsible for Down Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nondisjunction during meiosis I

  • Nondisjunction during meiosis I is the primary genetic mechanism responsible for Down syndrome, resulting in an extra copy of chromosome 21 in most cases.

Option A. Correct. Nondisjunction during meiosis I is the correct mechanism. This occurs when both copies of chromosome 21 fail to separate during the first division of cell division, resulting in an extra copy in one of the gametes (sperm or egg).

 

Option B. Incorrect. Nondisjunction during meiosis II is not the primary cause of Down syndrome. It can lead to other genetic disorders but is less common in Down syndrome.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Translocation Down syndrome occurs when a part of chromosome 21 attaches to another chromosome, typically chromosome 14, 21, or 22. This accounts for a small percentage of cases.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Trisomy of chromosome 22 is not associated with Down syndrome. The syndrome is specifically linked to an extra copy of chromosome 21.

choices.text: Posterior interosseous nerve

questions.text: Book test is for:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ulnar nerve

 

TESTS FOR ULNAR NERVE PALSY

  • Froment sign/book test: Hyperflexion of the thumb IP joint while attempting to pinch. This indicates a substitution of flexor pollicis longus (innervated by median nerve) for adductor pollicis (innervated by ulnar nerve).
  • Jeanne sign: reciprocal hyperextension of the thumb MCP joint indicating substitution of flexor pollicis longus (FPL) for adductor pollicis.
  • Wartenburg sign: Abduction of the small finger at MCP joint indicating deficient palmar intrinsic muscle (innervated by ulnar nerve) with abduction from extensor digiti minimi (innervated by the radial nerve).
  • Duchenne sign: Clawing of the ring and small fingers, hyperextension of MCP joints, and flexion of PIP joints indicating deficient interosseous and lumbrical muscles of the ring and small fingers.

questions.text:
A patient is brought into the emergency room after a severe car accident. The patient is unconscious and in critical condition, with multiple injuries. In this situation, the healthcare team may need to perform various surgical procedures, such as:

  • Emergency surgery to stop internal bleeding
  • Orthopedic surgery to repair broken bones
  • Neurosurgery to relieve pressure on the brain
  • Plastic surgery to address facial injuries
  • Thoracic surgery to treat lung injuries

Given the urgency of the situation and the patient's inability to provide specific consent, the healthcare team may ask a family member for consent to perform any necessary surgeries to stabilize and treat the patient's injuries, without giving details on specific type of surgery. This is a type of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Blanket Consent

  • Since detailed information on type of surgery is not provided, it is a blanket consent.
  • Consent can be of two types based on how much information provided on how much information provided:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Informed consent: Since detailed information on type of surgery is not provided to family member, it is not an informed consent.

 

Option B. Implied consent: Since the permission for doing surgery is specifically taken, it is an expressed consent (not implied).

 

Option D. Both B and C: This cannot be the answer as B choice is wrong.

questions.text: Rigor mortis be simulated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cadaveric spasm

  • Cadaveric spasm causes stiffening of body muscles, hence it simulates (looks similar to) rigor mortis.

  • Conditions Simulating (looking similar to) Rigor mortis as they cause body stiffening:

     

1. Cadaveric spasm:

  • Continuation of muscle contraction after death which were contracted at time of death
  • Occurs immediately after death
  • Only Selected muscles involved (Hands)
  • Intensity of muscle contraction is much more as compared to Rigor Mortis
  • Mechanism: Not known

2. Heat Stiffening (Pugilistic or Boxer’s attitude):

  • Shortening and stiffening of muscles due to coagulation of muscle proteins at body temperature > 65°C
  • Flexion of elbows, knees and clenching of hand into a fist
  • Intensity of muscle contraction is more as compared to Rigor Mortis

3. Cold Stiffening:

  • In freezing temperatures, the tissues become stiff, due to freezing of the body fluids
  • Body is extremely cold
  • On movement of joints, crepitus can be felt due to breaking down of frozen synovial fluid

4. Gas Stiffening:

  • Stiffening of the body due to putrefactive gases
  • Other signs of Putrefaction will be present
  • Not so stiff, joints can be easily moved

Other Options:

  • They do not cause body stiffening, hence not the answer.

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a patient has been admitted and there is a blood spillage on the hospital floor. Which type of disinfectant would you select for cleaning the floor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sodium hypochlorite

  • If there is spillage of blood on the hospital floor, sodium hypochlorite is the recommended disinfectant for cleaning the floor. This is because sodium hypochlorite has strong disinfectant properties and is effective against a broad spectrum of microorganisms, including blood-borne pathogens.
  • Procedure to be followed in the event of blood/body fluid spillage:
    1. Wear a pair of non-sterile gloves
    2. Broken glass (if any) of the container is cleaned first using tongs or a pan and brush and discarded in the sharp container. Caution is taken to not use hands.
    3. Disposable paper towels are used to absorb as much as possible.
    4. Water and detergent are used to clean the surface until visibly clean.
    5. The area is saturated with 0.5% Sodium Hypochlorite. This is prepared by diluting 5.25% sodium hypochlorite bleach at a 1:10 ratio.
    6. The tongs, pan, and brush are washed under running water and left to dry
    7. The gloves are removed and discarded.
    8. Hands are washed with soap and water using proper technique and dried with a disposable towel.
    9. The spillage is recorded in an incident book.

Other options:

 

Option A. Ethyl alcohol is not recommended for cleaning surfaces with blood spills as it is less effective against some microorganisms and may evaporate too quickly.

 

Option B. Chlorhexidine is also less effective against blood-borne pathogens and is better suited for skin disinfection.

 

Option D. Formaldehyde is not commonly used as a disinfectant due to its potential health hazards.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for primary infertility. Hysterosalpingography was done and reveals the finding shown below. What is the best treatment option for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hysteroscopic septal resection

  • The anomaly seen in the given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of a septate uterus.
  • A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts.
  • On HSG, a septate and bicornuate uterus are commonly mis-diagnosed.
  • If the angle between the 2 horns is < 75°, it is likely a septate uterus (As in this question).
  • If the angle between the 2 horns is >105°, then it is likely a bicornuate uterus.
  • However, an HSG is not the ideal investigation of choice.

Other Options:

  • IVF: This patient does not directly require an IVF, first the septum needs to be excised.
  • Strassman metroplasty: This is the surgery done for a bicornuate uterus.
  • Jones metroplasty: This is a surgery done for septate uterus but it is not preferred.

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn, 6th edition, Page no. 47

questions.text: A 34-year-old primi at 34 weeks develops preeclampsia. She has no other comorbidities. She asks if this could have been prevented and how?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Starting low dose aspirin before 12 weeks

  • Preeclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery.
  • The spiral artery supplies blood to the endometrium. In normal pregnancy, there is an invasion of the extravillous trophoblasts (specifically, endovascular trophoblasts) into the walls of the spiral arteries.
  • This takes place in 2 waves:
    • In the first wave of invasion (10-12 weeks), endovascular trophoblasts invade up to decidual segments.
    • In the second wave (16-18 weeks), they invade up to the myometrial segments.
       
  • This results in the distension of the spiral arterioles, thereby transforming them into a low resistance, low pressure, and high flow system.
  • In preeclampsia, the failure of the second wave of endovascular trophoblastic invasion into uterine vessels leads to decreased placental perfusion.
  • To prevent this, in women at risk of developing preeclampsia, they can be started on low dose aspirin (75-150 mg; preferably before 16 weeks)

 

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no. 1818

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with a history of progressive vision loss and night blindness. Upon examination, the patient displays characteristic retinal degeneration with peripheral bone spicule pigmentation. Which of the following syndromes is NOT likely associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Marfan syndrome

  • Usher’s syndrome is characterized by a combination of sensorineural hearing loss, progressive vision loss (often due to retinitis pigmentosa), and in some cases, vestibular dysfunction leading to balance issues.
  • Kornzweig syndrome is related to abetalipoproteinemia, leading to fat malabsorption and vitamin E deficiency but is not associated with these symptoms.
  • Kearns-Sayre syndrome typically presents with progressive external ophthalmoplegia, heart block, and other neurological features.
  • Marfan syndrome primarily affects connective tissues, causing skeletal, ocular, and cardiovascular abnormalities, but it does not typically include symptoms of retinal degeneration or hearing loss.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient with a history of HIV infection presents with recent laboratory findings showing elevated levels of liver enzymes. Further testing reveals that he is also co-infected with Hepatitis B Virus (HBV). The medical team is considering antiviral treatment that would act against both HIV and HBV. Which of the following antiviral drugs has dual antiviral activity against HIV and HBV?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Emtricitabine

  • Emtricitabine is a NRTI that has dual action against both HIV and Hepatitis B.
  • The drugs having activity against both HIV and HBV are:
    • L: Lamivudine
    • E: Emtricitabine
    • T: Tenofovir

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match with respect to the mechanism of action and clinical use of the given drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sparsentan – Dual endothelin and angiotensin receptor antagonist used for the treatment of CHF

  • Zavegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonist used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks by blocking the binding of CGRP to its receptors.
  • Sparsentan is a dual endothelin as well as angiotensin receptor antagonist used for the treatment of IgA nephrotpathy.
  • Lenacapavir is an HIV-1 capsid inhibitor used for the treatment of HIV infection by preventing the formation of functional HIV-1 capsids, which are necessary for the replication of the virus.
  • Teplizumab is an anti-CD3 monoclonal antibody used for the prevention of type 1 diabetes in high-risk individuals by modulating the immune response that attacks insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas.

questions.text: A middle-aged female on undergoing chest X-ray is found to have mediastinal widening. Upon further investigation, a 5.5 cm thoracic aortic aneurysm if found in descending aorta. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Wait and watch till it becomes 6 cm

  • In ascending aneurysms, the presence of progressive aortic valve insufficiency is an important indication for surgery. Other indications in this group, including Marfan-related aneurysms, are a diameter of 4.5-5 cm and the presence of symptoms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is brought to the ER in a state of unconsciousness. Her BP is 70/50 mm of Hg. Her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of her condition?

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a potential cause of short stature in a 4-year-old child who came with complaint of not gaining weight & height?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Turner syndrome is a genetic condition that can lead to short stature in females due to the absence or partial absence of one X chromosome.

 

Option A. Gigantism. Gigantism is a condition characterized by excessive growth and height, not short stature.

 

Option B. Incorrect. Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that often results in tall stature and long limbs, not short stature.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Acromegaly is a condition characterized by excessive growth of bones and tissues, leading to enlarged features. It is not associated with short stature.

  • Turner syndrome is a potential cause of short stature in children, as it affects female growth and development due to chromosome abnormalities.

choices.text: The accused cannot invoke Section 84 since the act was committed while not adhering to prescribed medication
Section 84 applies as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence
Section 84 is inapplicable due to the sporadic nature of the individual's symptoms
The accused can only invoke Section 84 if the act was committed during a state of complete unconsciousness

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual diagnosed with schizophrenia commits an act that would otherwise be considered a criminal offense. The act was committed during a period of acute psychotic episode. The individual's medical history indicates sporadic adherence to prescribed antipsychotic medication. The prosecution has charged the individual with the offense. Based on the provided information, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the applicability of Section 84 of IPC in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Section 84 applies if the accused's schizophrenia diagnosis is confirmed, regardless of medication adherence

  • Section 84 IPC: Act of a person of unsound mind
  • Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
  • Section 84 of the IPC provides a legal defense for individuals who commit an offense while they are of unsound mind. In this case, the individual has been diagnosed with schizophrenia, a recognized serious mental disorder. However, whether the accused was truly of unsound mind at the time of the offense would depend on the severity of the symptoms during that period, which in this case was indeed severe (an acute psychotic episode).

Other Options:

 

Option A. The accused cannot invoke Section 84 since the act was committed while not adhering to prescribed medication. The adherence to medication is not required in 84 IPC.

 

Option C. Section 84 is inapplicable due to the sporadic nature of the individual's symptoms. At the time of commission of offence, the victim should be of unsound mind for 84 IPC. In this case then, victim had psychotic episode during crime.

 

Option D. The accused can only invoke Section 84 if the act was committed during a state of complete unconsciousness. Unsoundness of mind is required, not unconsciousness.

choices.text: It is involved in the creation of Okazaki fragments
It is found in prokaryotes
It synthesizes RNA primers
It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Kornberg’s enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is found in prokaryotes

  • DNA polymerase I (Kornberg’s enzyme) from Escherichia coli (prokaryote). It is a repair enzyme. It has both 3′ to 5′ and 5′ to 3′ exonuclease activities. When 5′ to 3′ exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called Klenow fragment. It is widely used in recombinant DNA technology.
  • DNA polymerases I, II, and III are prokaryotic polymerases.
  • DNA polymerase II: DNA proofreading and repair.
  • DNA polymerase III: Main replication enzyme in bacteria
  • In mammalian cells (eukaryotic), there are 5 DNA polymerases (DNAPs) named as α, β, γ, δ and ε.
  • DNAP Alpha polymerizes about 100 nucleotides per second (Bacterial enzyme has 10 times more speed). It is the major enzyme which synthesizes Okazaki fragments. It has 4 subunits, of which one has primase activity.
  • DNAP delta is mainly responsible for leading strand synthesis and also elongates the Okazaki fragments.
  • DNAP beta is a proofreading and repair enzyme.
  • DNAP gamma is concerned with mitochondrial DNA replication.
  • DNAP Epsilon is involved in damage repair.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with complaints of pain, numbness, and darkening of the lower extremities. Physical examination reveals gangrene in the feet and lower legs. The patient reports a history of residing in an area with known arsenic-contaminated drinking water. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Blackfoot disease

BLACKFOOT DISEASE

  • Arsenic, cadmium, lead and mercury are the heavy metals which can cause peripheral vascular disease due to chronic poisoning. This leads to general clinical features of peripheral vascular disease (numbness in feet, rest pain etc.).
  • Blackfoot disease is a unique term given to peripheral vascular disease produced by chronic Arsenic poisoning. The name "Blackfoot" refers to the characteristic darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs. This ultimately leads to amputation.
  • In peripheral vascular disease caused by other heavy metals, gangrene is not a common manifestation.
  • Below picture shows Blackfoot disease:

Other Options:

  • Option A (Deep vein thrombosis) involves the formation of blood clots in deep veins, typically in the legs. While it can cause pain and swelling, it does not lead to the specific pattern of darkening and necrosis seen in Blackfoot disease.
  • Option C (Raynaud's phenomenon) is characterized by episodes of reduced blood flow to the fingers and toes, causing them to turn white, then blue, and then red. Gangrene is not a typical manifestation of Raynaud's phenomenon.
  • Option D (Diabetic neuropathy) involves nerve damage due to diabetes, leading to symptoms such as pain, numbness, and tingling in the extremities. While diabetes can contribute to peripheral artery disease and related complications, the specific presentation of gangrene is more indicative of Blackfoot disease in this case.

choices.text: History of similar illness in the past
History of fever
History of vaccination

questions.text: A man from Chhattisgarh presented with a gradual onset of muscle weakness and spasms in his legs. On examination, there was a specific loss of motor function. What inquiries should be made to gather the most relevant medical history from this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. History of diet

  • The clinical presentation suggests that the patient may have neurolathyrism, which is caused by the excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal.
  • To confirm the diagnosis, it is important to obtain the patient's dietary history.
  • Neurolathyrism is a paralytic condition caused by the consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal, which is common in certain regions of India such as Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Odisha, and Bihar.
  • The disease mainly affects the nervous system, causing gradual spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. It primarily affects males between the ages of 15 and 45 years and progresses through several stages.
  • The toxin responsible for the disease is BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine), which is water-soluble and can be removed from the pulses by soaking them in hot water and discarding the water.
  • Large-scale detoxification can be achieved by parboiling the crop, or by overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling.
  • Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can help prevent and treat lathyrism.
  • In India, the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act prohibits the use of Lathyrus sativus in any form (whole/split/flour).

choices.text: Applying a tourniquet above the bite site to restrict blood flow and prevent venom spread
Cutting open the wound and attempting to suck out the venom
Immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and transporting the person to a medical facility
Applying ice packs directly to the bite area to reduce swelling and pain

questions.text: A hiker in a forested area is bitten by a snake while exploring. Hiker begins to experience symptoms such as swelling, pain, and bruising at the bite site. The hiker remains conscious but is anxious. What is the most appropriate initial first aid response for this snake bite?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and transporting the person to a medical facility

  • The appropriate first aid response for a snake bite involves immobilizing the affected limb (if the bite is on an extremity) and keeping it at or slightly below heart level. This helps slow the spread of venom through the lymphatic system. Use a splint or any available materials to immobilize limb.
  • First Aid treatment outside the hospital setting has very limited role in snake bite management. The first aid treatment can be divided in three categories:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Applying a tourniquet above the bite site to restrict blood flow and prevent venom spread. It can lead to gangrene.

 

Option B. Cutting open the wound and attempting to suck out the venom. It can introduce infections, increase absorption of the venom and increase local bleeding

 

Option D. Applying ice packs directly to the bite area to reduce swelling and pain. While ice packs are recommended in scorpion bite, it is not to be given in snake bite. Snake venom can contain enzymes that cause tissue damage and affect blood circulation. Cold temperature can constrict blood vessels and worsen the local damage.

questions.text: Which is NOT a predictor of pre-eclampsia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Beta hCG

 

PREDICTORS OF PREECLAMPSIA

  • History and Mean Arterial Pressure
  • Biophysical markers: Raised PI in the uterine Artery (11-14 weeks); notching of uterine Artery waveform (mid trimester) is a marker of early onset Pre-eclampsia
  • Biochemical markers: 

  • S-Flt-1 and s-Eng are anti-angiogenic factors.
  • Tests done earlier (No longer done):
    • Roll over test: 28- 32 weeks: BP is measured with patient on her side first and then she is asked to roll on her back and BP is checked again -an increase of 20mmHg in diastolic BP from lateral to supine position is a positive test – 30% of such women will develop pre-eclampsia in the future. 
    • Angiotensin II sensitivity test: Rise in BP with Angiotensin II infusion. 
       
  • If at RISK of developing pre-eclampsia, start low dose Aspirin 75-150mg before 16 weeks.

 

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no. 1818

Ans. D. Uterine inversion

  • The maneuver shown is the Brandt-Andrews maneuver used in controlled cord traction for delivery of the placenta.
  • In this technique, one hand pulls on the cord and the other hand applies supra pubic pressure above to prevent acute uterine inversion
  • Controlled cord traction should be performed in all deliveries to deliver the placenta

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no. 674

questions.text: Defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Type 1 Tyrosinemia

 

HEPATORENAL TYROSINEMIA (TYROSINEMIA TYPE I) AKA TYROSINOSIS 

  • Autosomal recessive, most common type of tyrosinemia.
  • Due to a deficiency of enzyme fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase.
  • Symptoms manifest by the first 6 months of life and death occurs rapidly. Cabbage-like odor and hypoglycemia and eventual liver failure are seen. There may be mild mental retardation.
  • Urine contains tyrosine, para-hydroxyphenyl pyruvic acid (p-HPPA) and hydroxyphenyl lactic acid; and serum shows tyrosine.
  • Tyrosine and phenylalanine restricted diet is advised.
  • Oculocutaneous Tyrosinemia/Richner-Hanhart Syndrome (Tyrosinemia Type II) is due to deficiency of tyrosine amino transferase (tyrosine transaminase). Mental retardation, keratosis of palmar surface, painful corneal lesions and photophobia are seen. There is increased excretion of tyrosine and tyramine in urine. A diet low in protein is advised.
  • Neonatal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type III) is due to the absence of the enzyme para-hydroxyphenylpyruvate hydroxylase. This deficiency may cause transient hypertyrosinemia in the new born; this will respond to administration of ascorbic acid and dietary protein restriction.

questions.text: A child presents with bone pain and hepatosplenomegaly. A trephine biopsy and aspirate show the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Glucocerebrosidase

  • The given clinical vignette of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance points to diagnosis of Gaucher's disease, in which enzyme deficient is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase).

questions.text: A patient presented with the following appearance on his upper trunk as shown below along with diarrhoea. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies would you suspect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Vitamin B3 deficiency

  • The above image shows casal necklace appearance which is typical feature of Vitamin B3 deficiency.
  • The given clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhoea, dermatitis, and dementia is suggestive of niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency.

VITAMIN B3 (ALSO CALLED NIACIN, NICOTINIC ACID)

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B1/Thiamine deficiency can manifest as wet beriberi (CVS features like heart failure and edema), dry beriberi (peripheral neuritis), or as Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis (in alcoholics). Dietary deficiency of thiamine inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6/Pyridoxine deficiency causes Convulsions, hyperirritability, peripheral neuropathy (deficiency inducible by isoniazid and oral contraceptives), sideroblastic anemia (due to impaired hemoglobin synthesis and iron excess)

 

Option D. Vitamin B12/Cobalamin deficiency causes Macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia; paraesthesia and subacute combined degeneration due to abnormal myelin. Associated with ↑ serum homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels, along with 2° folate deficiency.

choices.text: CSOM with intratemporal and intracranial complications

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of ear discharge with associated fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, vertigo and tinnitus. Which condition below aptly suits the presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CSOM with intratemporal and intracranial complications

  • Vertigo and tinnitus indicates involvement of inner ear (labyrinth), hence labyrinthitis can be suspected here. It is intratemporal complication. Headache, nausea, vomiting indicates increased intracranial tension. Hence, intracranial complications can be suspected clinically in this case.

questions.text: A patient present with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. 24-hour urine volume was measured and recorded to be 7 liters. The urine osmolarity was 260 mOsm/L. ADH assay was performed and the recorded values were reported as 0.8 pg/ml. An MRI of the brain was performed and T1 weighted indicated the absence of the bright spot. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pituitary DI

 

APPROACH TO POLYURIA

 

Water vs solute diuresis (first thing to know)

  • Water diuresis: DI, Primary polydipsia
  • Solute diuresis:
    • Glycosuria (Hyperglycemia, SGLT2 inhibitor use)
    • Iatrogenic hyper-osmolar agents (Hypertonic saline, Mannitol, Urea from high-protein tube feeding, Radiocontrast agents)
    • Salt wasting (e.g., Medullary cystic disease, Diuretics, CSWS, Obstructive uropathy especially, if B/L, resolving ATN)
       
  • MMS algorithm for finding out the cause:

 

 

  • Before giving desmopressin, S. Na+ should be 145 (or) P. Osm should be > 295. If this cannot be achieved (usually due to severe thirst) during water deprivation, alternative for water deprivation is Hypertonic saline infusion to achieve S. Na >145 or P. Osm >295, then desmopressin test can be performed.
  • Hypertonic saline (to ↑P. Osm) + Plasma AVP measurement in response to ↑P. Osm due to hypertonic saline. Plasma AVP is unstable and needs stringent storage techniques. Based on AVP levels, can diagnose pituitary vs nephrogenic vs primary polydipsia. Diagnostic accuracy is questionable.

**Plasma Co-Peptin (analogues to C-peptide of insulin) can be used for central vs nephrogenic DI

questions.text: According to the Factories Act of 1948, what is the maximum permissible weekly working hours, including of overtime?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 60 hours

  • Maximum work hours per week including overtime work hours is 60 hours.
  • Factories Act (Established in 1948):
    • Established to include all the factories except Defense, Mining, Railways and Eateries.
    • Per capita space: more than 500/ft3
    • One Safety officer for more than 1000 workers.
    • Children between 14-18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM-7PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.
    • The maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48 hours per week or less than 9 hours per day.
    • With overtime being included, it should not be more than 60 hours per week.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a history of heavy smoking and is known to have hypertension. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals changes consistent with an acute myocardial infarction (heart attack). The healthcare team orders laboratory tests, including a measurement of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) isoenzymes. The flipped LDH ratio is observed. What does this flipped LDH ratio imply regarding the LDH isoenzyme levels in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. LDH 1 > LDH 2

  • Normally, LDH 2 is predominant in the blood and LDH 1 is predominant in the heart. During a myocardial infarction, due to damage to the cardiac tissue, LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream resulting in a high LDH 1 : LDH 2 ratio called flipped LDH ratio (LDH 1 > LDH 2).

 

TYPES OF LDH

  • LDH-1: Heart
  • LDH-2: Blood
  • LDH-3: Brain, kidney, lungs, spleen, pancreas
  • LDH-4: Liver and skeletal muscle
  • LDH-5: Liver and skeletal muscle

Factors II, VII, IX, and X
Factors II, VII, IX, XI
Factors II, VIII, X, XI

questions.text: Which of the following zymogens requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Factors II, VII, IX, and X

  • Clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X are zymogens of serine proteases that contain glutamic acid residues. These residues undergo Vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation via gamma-glutamyl carboxylase to form gamma-carboxy glutamic acid residues. This enables them to bind calcium ions (Ca2+), which is necessary for their activation and subsequent blood clot formation.
  • Zymogens are the proprotein form of enzymes (proenzymes) that require proteolytic activation to carry out their function.
  • Inactive form of vitamin K acts as a cofactor in the post-synthetic modification of these zymogens and their activation. This inactive form of vitamin K is recycled back from its oxidized form by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which can be inhibited by warfarin or liver failure.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his concerned family. Over the past 4 days, he has become increasingly irritable, with markedly reduced sleep. On evaluation, the young man is observed to be speaking incessantly. Even when attempts are made to interrupt or redirect him, he persists with his verbalizations, claiming to have personal connections with the Prime Minister and the President of the country. Given the abruptness of onset and the observed clinical features, the decision is made to admit him to a psychiatric facility. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mania

  • The patient's symptoms, including reduced need for sleep, irritability, pressured speech (talking continuously without being easily interrupted), and grandiose delusions (believing he knows high-profile leaders personally) are characteristic of a manic episode.
  • Here's the differentiation among the choices:

Option A. Mania: This is characterized by a distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood lasting at least one week (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary). During this period, symptoms like inflated self-esteem or grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, talkativeness, flight of ideas, distractibility, and excessive involvement in risky activities are observed.

 

Option B. Hypomania: This resembles a manic episode but is of shorter duration (at least 4 days) and is not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization. There are no psychotic features.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: This is a chronic mental disorder characterized by periods of psychosis with hallucinations (typically auditory), delusions, and disorganized thinking. The symptoms described do not match the typical presentation of schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Schizoaffective disorder: This involves symptoms of both schizophrenia (like hallucinations or delusions) and a mood disorder (like mania or depression). The patient would need to have a period where only the mood or only the psychotic symptoms are present, and the provided vignette does not provide enough evidence of this.

  • Educational Objective: The presence of symptoms like grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, and pressured speech can indicate manic episode, even if the duration criteria does not meet, provided it is severe enough for hospitalization.

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition

choices.text: It typically presents with joint pain and arthritis
The primary cause of Kawasaki disease is a bacterial infection
One of its most critical complications is coronary artery aneurysm
It is more common in teenagers and adults than in young children

questions.text: Kawasaki disease is a rare pediatric vasculitis that primarily affects young children. Which of the following statements about Kawasaki disease is CORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. One of its most critical complications is coronary artery aneurysm

  • Coronary artery aneurysm underscores the importance of early diagnosis and treatment to prevent serious cardiac issues.

Option A. Incorrect. Kawasaki disease does not typically present with joint pain and arthritis. Instead, it is characterized by a set of clinical features that include prolonged high fever, redness of the eyes, changes in the lips and oral cavity, skin rash, and swollen hands and feet.

 

Option B. Incorrect. The exact cause of Kawasaki disease is not well understood, but it is believed to involve an abnormal immune response, possibly triggered by an infection. However, it is not primarily caused by a bacterial infection.

 

Option C. Correct. One of the most critical complications of Kawasaki disease is coronary artery aneurysm. Inflammation of the coronary arteries can lead to the formation of aneurysms, which can result in serious cardiovascular problems, including heart attacks, blood clots, and rupture of the artery wall.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Kawasaki disease primarily affects young children, with the highest incidence occurring in those under the age of five. It is rare in teenagers and adults.

choices.text: It is a form of neural tube defect (NTD)
Craniorachischisis typically occurs in isolation without other associated anomalies
Surgical intervention is not required in cases of craniorachischisis
This condition primarily affects the circulatory system

questions.text: Craniorachischisis is a severe congenital anomaly of the central nervous system. Which of the following statements about craniorachischisis is CORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It is a form of neural tube defect (NTD)

  • It is characterized by the complete failure of the neural tube to close during embryonic development, resulting in an open spinal cord and brain.
  • Craniorachischisis is a severe form of NTD where both the brain and spinal cord remain open, leading to significant neurological and developmental challenges.

Option B. Incorrect. Craniorachischisis is often associated with other congenital anomalies, such as facial abnormalities, limb defects, and organ malformations, making it a complex condition with multiple associated anomalies.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Surgical intervention is typically required in cases of craniorachischisis. The exposed neural tissue is vulnerable to infection and damage, and surgical closure is necessary to protect the spinal cord and brain.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Craniorachischisis primarily affects the central nervous system, specifically the neural tube, and is not related to the circulatory system.

choices.text: Diarrhoea is typically defined by having bowel movements less than three times a day
Viral infections are not a common cause of acute diarrhoea
Chronic diarrhoea is often associated with a short duration of symptoms
Dehydration can be a serious complication of diarrhoea

questions.text: A 4-year-old female patient came with complaints of 8 episodes of loose stool. On further examination, child had severe dehydration. Which of the following statements about diarrhoea is CORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dehydration can be a serious complication of diarrhoea

  • Emphasizing the importance of staying hydrated when experiencing diarrhoea to prevent potential health risks.

Option A. Incorrect. Diarrhoea is typically defined by having frequent, loose, and watery bowel movements, often exceeding three times a day. The frequency and consistency of stool are key criteria in diagnosing diarrhoea.

 

Option B. Incorrect. Viral infections, such as rotavirus and norovirus, are common causes of acute diarrhoea, especially in children and adults. Bacterial and parasitic infections can also lead to acute diarrhoea.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Chronic diarrhoea is characterized by persistently loose or frequent stools that last for at least four weeks. It is the opposite of acute diarrhoea, which has a short duration and is often caused by infections.

 

Option D. Correct. Dehydration is a serious complication of diarrhoea. Excessive fluid loss due to diarrhoea can lead to dehydration, which can be particularly dangerous, especially in infants, young children, and the elderly. It is essential to address dehydration by replenishing fluids and electrolytes when experiencing diarrhoea.

questions.text: What levels of prolactin are definitely suggestive of prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. >200ug/L

 

 

Option A, B, C are not the right explanation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient with a 15-year history of poorly controlled diabetes presents to the ophthalmology clinic with visual disturbances. On fundoscopic examination, you observe multiple haemorrhages, micro aneurysms, and hard exudates in both eyes. However, one eye has a presentation more than the other. There is a lesion near the macula with vascularization and fluid accumulation, causing severe visual impairment. The patient reports no recent trauma. Which of the following findings is atypical for diabetic retinopathy in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Choroidal neovascular membrane formation

  • In diabetic retinopathy, the most common complications are micro aneurysms, haemorrhages, hard exudates, and neovascularization within the retina (proliferative diabetic retinopathy).
  • However, choroidal neovascular membrane formation, which involves the growth of abnormal blood vessels from the choroid layer beneath the retina, is not a typical feature of diabetic retinopathy.
  • It is more commonly associated with other eye conditions like age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

questions.text: PICA is a behaviour characterized by the persistent consumption of non-nutritive, non-food substances. Which of the following is a common example of a substance craved by individuals with PICA?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ice

  • Ice is a common example of a non-food substance craved by individuals with PICA. PICA involves the consumption of substances with little to no nutritional value, often posing health risks due to potential complications from ingesting non-food items.

Option A. Incorrect. Raw meat consumption is not typically associated with PICA. PICA usually involves non-food items like clay, chalk, paper, or ice.

 

Option B. Correct. Ice is a common example of a non-nutritive, non-food substance craved by individuals with PICA. This behaviour is referred to as "pagophagia."

 

Option C. Incorrect. Fresh fruits are considered nutritious food items and are not typically associated with PICA.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Cooked vegetables are also nutritious food items and are not typically craved by individuals with PICA.

questions.text: A 56-year-old previously healthy physician notices that his eyes are yellow and he has been losing weight. On physical examination, the patient has jaundice and scleral icterus with a palpable gall bladder lump. Transcutaneous ultrasound of the abdomen demonstrates biliary ductal dilation without gallstones. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the workup of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)

  • Painless jaundice with weight loss is suspicious for a pancreatic cancer involving the head or uncinate process of the pancreas.
  • A helical contrast enhanced CT scan is the most appropriate study to evaluate for a pancreatic mass.
  • CT has a specificity of 95% or better with sensitivity exceeding 95% for tumors larger than 2 cm in diameter.
  • An ERCP is helpful in evaluating patients with obstructive jaundice without a detectable mass on CT scan.
  • An MRCP is preferred when CBD stones are suspected, and is not the first step in the evaluation of a patient with a suspected pancreatic mass.
  • EUS is beneficial in local staging of pancreatic masses.

choices.text: In TAPVC, pulmonary veins connect normally to the left atrium
TAPVC allows for normal oxygenated blood flow to the body
Surgical correction is not typically required for TAPVC
TAPVC results in pulmonary veins connecting abnormally to the right atrium

questions.text: Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC) is a congenital heart defect involving the abnormal connection of pulmonary veins. Which of the following statements about TAPVC is CORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. TAPVC results in pulmonary veins connecting abnormally to the right atrium

  • TAPVC involves pulmonary veins connecting abnormally to the right atrium or other heart structures, disrupting the normal oxygenated blood flow, and necessitating surgical correction.

Option A. Incorrect. In TAPVC, pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium, which is the typical connection. Instead, they connect abnormally.

 

Option B. Incorrect. TAPVC disrupts the normal circulation of oxygenated blood, as pulmonary veins connect abnormally, often draining into the right atrium. This leads to inadequate oxygenation of blood that circulates to the body.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Surgical correction is typically required for TAPVC. The goal of surgery is to reroute the pulmonary veins so that they connect to the left atrium, allowing for normal oxygenated blood flow.

 

Option D. Correct. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC) is characterized by pulmonary veins connecting abnormally to the right atrium or other heart structures instead of connecting to the left atrium, as they should. This results in a mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood and typically requires surgical intervention for correction.

choices.text: Patient age of older than 25 years

questions.text: An ultrasound is performed on a patient with right upper quadrant pain. It demonstrates a large gallstone in the cystic duct but also a polypoid mass in the fundus. Which of the following is an indication for cholecystectomy for a polypoid gallbladder lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Presence of clinical symptoms

  • Symptomatic lesions should be removed regardless of their size.
  • Polypoid lesions of the gallbladder are found most often in the third through fifth decades of life and are increasingly being detected by ultrasonography. These are generally small lesions that typically do not show a shadow on ultrasound (option D). Ninety percent are benign lesions, such as cholesterol polyps (pseudotumors). Does, mere absence of shadowing doesn’t imply surgical removal.
  • True adenomas, which constitute about 10% of these benign lesions, can undergo malignant transformation. The indications for operative intervention remain controversial. Recent reviews suggest that the vast majority of malignant polypoid lesions are solitary, larger than 1.0 cm, and much more common in patients older than 50 years of age. There is also an increased incidence of malignancy if the lesions are associated with gallstones.
  • Asymptomatic small lesions can probably be safely followed by ultrasonography.

choices.text: As a screening test for colorectal cancer
To determine which patients should receive adjuvant therapy
To determine which patients should receive neoadjuvant therapy
To monitor for post-operative recurrence

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents with adenocarcinoma of the right colon. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates an elevation of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) to 123 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate use of CEA testing in patients with colorectal cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. To monitor for post-operative recurrence

  • A CEA level is most useful as a marker for postoperative recurrence in colorectal cancer.
  • A level is obtained every 3 months during the first 2 years after surgery to detect early recurrence that is amenable to treatment.
  • CEA is a nonspecific tumor marker that is elevated in only about one-half of patients with colorectal tumors and is often elevated in patients with lung, pancreatic, gastric, or gynaecologic malignancies.
  • Use of CEA level as a screening test for colorectal cancer is not recommended.
  • Although preoperative elevation of CEA level is an indicator of poor prognosis, CEA levels are not used to determine whether to give a patient adjuvant (or neoadjuvant) therapy.
  • CEA levels are not routinely used in the preoperative setting to evaluate for metastasis in colorectal cancer.
  • Most surgeons obtain a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to evaluate for metastases.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis pathway?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Palmitic acid

  • Fatty acids are synthesized from acetyl CoA mainly by a de novo synthetic pathway operating in the cytoplasm referred to as extramitochondrial or cytoplasmic fatty acid synthase system.
  • The major fatty acid synthesized de novo is palmitic acid, the 16C saturated fatty acid. The process occurs in liver, adipose tissue, kidney, brain, and mammary glands.
  • Beta oxidation of fatty acids breaks it down into Acetyl CoA.

 

  • Defect in pathway: Inhibition of lipogenesis occurs in type 1 (insulin-dependent) diabetes mellitus, and variations in its activity affect the nature and extent of obesity.

choices.text: Sudden onset of cardio-pulmonary compromise
DIC following initial symptoms

questions.text: A 30-year-old P2L2 immediately collapses as soon as the placenta is delivered. Her pulse is not recordable, and her BP is 80/40 mmHg. She is gasping for breath. Immediately CPR is initiated, and amniotic fluid embolism is suspected. Which is NOT a criterion for diagnosis amniotic fluid embolism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fever > 38°C

 

AMNIOTIC FLUID EMBOLISM

  • Complex condition characterized by abrupt onset of pulmonary embolism, shock and DIC which is due to entering of amniotic fluid into the maternal circulation.
  • Incidence: 1 in 8,000 to 1 in 80,000 pregnancies.
  • Time of event:
    • During labor (history may be occurring after artificial rupture of membranes)
    • During C/S
    • After normal vaginal delivery
  • Criteria for Diagnosis (Williams 26th edition):
    • Sudden onset of cardiopulmonary arrest or both Hypotension and Respiratory compromise
    • DIC following initial symptoms
    • Onset during labor or within 30 minutes of delivery
    • No fever (>38.0°C) during labor

 

 

Ref: Williams Obstetric 26th edition, Page no. 743-745

choices.text: Ubiquitination of proteins

questions.text: What do chaperones assist in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Protein folding

  • Chaperones help to produce the correct spatial arrangement in proteins. Chaperones attach to nascent polypeptide chains and prevent wrong folding; so that folding is allowed only in the correct direction. They help in the assembly of tertiary and quaternary structure of proteins.
  • Examples of chaperones are a large family of proteins called heat shock proteins (HSPs). Any stress to the cell including heat, toxins, heavy metals, free radicals, radiation, bacteria, etc. will cause increased production of HSPs, and hence they are more correctly termed as stress proteins.
  • Improper protein folding may lead to prion diseases.
  • Examples:
    • BIP (Immunogloulin Heavy Chain Binding Protein)
    • GRP – 78 (Glucose Regulated Protein – 78)
    • GRP – 94 
    • GRP – 170
    • Calnexin
    • Calreticulin
    • HSP – 40 (also known as Cochaperone)
    • HSP – 47 (Heat Shock Protein – 47)
    • HSP – 70
    • HSP – 90
    • ERp – 29 (Endoplasmic Reticulum protein)
    • ERp – 57

choices.text: Exploratory laparotomy, gastrotomy, and oversewing of the tear

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman with a history of unstable angina complains of hematemesis after retching and vomiting following a night of binge drinking. Endoscopy reveals a longitudinal mucosal tear at the gastroesophageal junction, which is not actively bleeding. Which of the following is the next recommended step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Expectant management

  • Most of the time (90%), the bleeding from Mallory-Weiss syndrome will stop without any intervention.
  • In these cases, further treatment is not necessary.
  • Patients with Mallory-Weiss syndrome typically present with a massive, painless hematemesis after severe vomiting or retching.
  • The majority of tears occur just below the gastroesophageal junction.
  • These tears occur more commonly in cirrhotics than in the normal population.
  • When bleeding persists, balloon tamponade, endoscopic control of the bleeding, and surgical intervention with gastrotomy and oversewing of the tear have all been successful.
