questions.text: You are examining a primigravida in the second stage of labor. She has been fully dilated since 3 hours and is tired. On examination, contractions are adequate, the cervix is fully dilated with the head at +2 station. The contractions are good. There is mild caput and no moulding. The sagittal suture is in the right occipito-anterior position. The fetal heart rate is 150 beats/minute with occasional decelerations up to 100 bpm with contractions. Which of the following is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vacuum-assisted delivery

  • This is a situation of prolonged 2nd stage with maternal exhaustion.
  • There are no features of obstruction and uterine contractions are good.
  • Early decelerations are expected in the 2nd stage due to head compression.
  • Rotation is at 45° (ROA).
  • Station is at +2.
  • Keeping all these in mind,
    • The best option would be to apply a vacuum.
    • The station is too high to apply some outlet forceps.
    • An LSCS is not indicated as of now as there is no evidence of CPD or obstruction.
    • The upper limit of waiting in 2nd stage in a primi is 3 hours, hence further waiting for an hour is not indicated.

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no. 661

questions.text: All are caused by staphylococcal infection except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Erysipelas, scarlet fever

  • Erysipelas and scarlet fever are not typically caused by staphylococcal infection.

Option A. Impetigo contagiosa, carbuncle:

  • Impetigo contagiosa: Caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes bacteria. It leads to contagious, superficial skin sores.
  • Carbuncle: Also caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Option B. SSSS (Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome), toxic shock syndrome:

  • SSSS: Caused by specific strains of Staphylococcus aureus. It results in widespread skin blistering and peeling.
  • Toxic shock syndrome: Often associated with Staphylococcus aureus. It is characterized by fever, rash, and organ dysfunction.

Option C. Ecthyma, Furuncle:

  • Ecthyma: Typically caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus aureus. It leads to painful ulcers on the skin.
  • Furuncle (boil): Caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It is a localized skin infection with painful, red indurated lesions.

Option D. Erysipelas, scarlet fever:

  • Erysipelas: Primarily caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus). It results in skin inflammation with raised, well-defined borders.
  • Scarlet fever: Also primarily caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. It is characterized by a rash, fever, and sore throat.

choices.text: Oral amoxicillin for five days
Urgent referral to the tertiary care center immediately
Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours
Start antipyretics urgently

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the pediatric outpatient clinic, weighing 11 kilograms. The child displayed a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute, and during the examination, chest indrawing was observed. What should be the subsequent course of action in terms of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Oral amoxicillin for five days

  • According to the latest revised guidelines by WHO, in this case, oral amoxicillin should be given for 5 days

choices.text: Prodromal stage of angle closure glaucoma
Acute attack of acute closure glaucoma

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady presented with a history of seeing coloured halos in the evening. On examination, her Intraocular pressure was normal. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Prodromal stage of angle closure glaucoma

  • In this case, the 40-year-old lady experiencing coloured halos in the evening suggests the prodromal stage of angle closure glaucoma.
  • This stage is characterized by intermittent symptoms such as halos, blurred vision, and ocular discomfort.
  •  Intraocular pressure may still be normal at this stage, but the symptoms indicate a risk of progressing to an acute attack if not treated promptly.
  • Acute closure glaucoma (option B) typically presents with sudden and severe symptoms, while chronic angle closure glaucoma (option C) would have a more gradual onset and may lead to visual field defects over time.
  • Mature cataract (option D) is unrelated to these glaucoma symptoms.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation with lower abdominal pain. She has been in labor for 3 hours. She is currently 5 cm dilated and well effaced. The station of the head is -1 and the membranes are absent. Which stage of labor is she in?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Active stage

  • As per the WHO Labor Care Guide (LCG), active labor begins at > 5 cm cervical dilatation.
  • The older definition of active labor was 4 cm.
  • First stage of labor is defined as from onset of true labor pains till full dilatation of the cervix. This is further divided into:
    • Latent phase (till 5 cm cervical dilatation)
    • Active phase (≥ 5 cm cervical dilatation)
  • Second stage of labor: From full dilatation till delivery of the baby
  • Third stage: From delivery of the baby till delivery of placenta
  • Fourth stage: Following delivery of placenta to 1 hour of observation

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no. 138

choices.text: Inflammation with purulent discharge
No inflammation with purulent discharge
Inflammation without purulent discharge
No inflammation, no purulent discharge

questions.text: Multifocal non-suppurative osteomyelitis is characterized by:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inflammation without purulent discharge

 

MULTIFOCAL NON-SUPPURATIVE OSTEOMYELITIS

  • Focal sterile inflammatory disease with prolonged, self-limiting and recurring episodes. It has been seen to be associated with SAPHO syndrome (Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, palmo-plantar Hyperostosis and Osteitis).
  • Despite the local and systemic signs of inflammation, there is no purulent discharge and microbes are seldom isolated. This is a diagnosis of exclusion.

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

Presenting Complaints:

  • A chronic discharging sinus is the commonest presenting symptom. The onset of sinus may be traced back to an episode of acute osteomyelitis during childhood.
  • Often sinuses heal for short periods, only to reappear with each acute exacerbation.
  • Discharge: Quality of discharge varies from seropurulent to thick pus. There may be a history of extrusion of small bone fragments from the sinus.
  • Pain: Pain is usually minimal but may become aggravated during acute exacerbations. Generalized symptoms of infection such as fever etc., are present only during acute exacerbations.

Radiological Features:

  • Thickening and irregularity of the cortices
  • Patchy sclerosis
  • Bone cavity: This is seen as an area of rarefaction surrounded by sclerosis.
  • Sequestrum: Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. This appears denser than the surrounding normal bone because the decalcification which occurs in normal bone, does not occur in dead bone. Granulation tissue surrounding the sequestrum gives rise to a radiolucent zone around it. A sequestrum may be visible in soft tissues.
  • Involucrum is the dense sclerotic bone overlying a sequestrum. There may be some holes in the involucrum for pus to drain out. These holes are called cloacae.

Treatment:

  • Treatment of chronic osteomyelitis is primarily surgical. Antibiotics are useful only during acute exacerbations and during postoperative period.

Various surgical options are:

  • Sequestrectomy
  • Saucerisation
  • Curettage
  • Excision of an infected bone
  • Amputation

choices.text: It is the narrowest part of the pelvis
It is at the level of the ischial tuberosity
The curvature of the pelvis changes at this plane
Deep transverse arrests occur at this plane

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a feature of the plane marked in orange?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is at the level of the ischial tuberosity

 

PLANE OF LEAST PELVIC DIMENSION

  • At the level of ischial spine
  • Very important plane CLINICALLY
    1. Narrowest part of pelvis
    2. Internal rotation takes place here
    3. Origin of levator ani
    4. Landmark for pudendal block
    5. When engagement occurs, the head is felt at 0 station, i.e. at this plane
    6. Deep Transverse Arrest occurs here

 

 

Ref: Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma, Page no. 92

choices.text: At the umbilicus
Two finger breadths below umbilicus
Midway between the umbilicus and the pubic symphysis
Just above the pubic symphysis

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida has a vaginal delivery. She visits for a postnatal check up on the 10th postnatal day. At what level will the uterus be palpable on abdominal examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Just above the pubic symphysis

  • Following delivery, the uterus is at the level of the umbilicus.
  • Following this, it involutes (Reduces in size).
    • It involutes 1F/day form the 1st day onwards.
    • So, on the 2nd day post-delivery, the uterus will be felt 2F breadth below the umbilicus.
    • It becomes a pelvic organ (no longer abdominally palpable) by 10-14 days.
    • It becomes the size of a non-pregnant uterus by 6 weeks.
       
  • So, on the 10th day, the uterus will be just above the pubic symphysis/no longer palpable abdominally.

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no. 169

choices.text: Herpes simplex infection

questions.text: A 19-year-old female college student has fever, sore throat and lymphadenopathy accompanied by lymphocytosis with atypical cells and an increase in sheep cell agglutinins. Diagnosis is most likely:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Infectious mononucleosis

  • EBV causes infectious mononucleosis.
  • After an incubation period of 30-50 days, symptoms of head ache, fever, malaise, fatigue and sore throat occur. Enlarged lymph nodes and spleen are characteristic. Some develop signs of hepatitis.
  • Self-limited, lasts for 2-4 weeks.
  • Increase in WBC count with predominance of lymphocytes. Many of these are large, atypical T lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with severe eye pain, redness, and sensitivity to light in their right eye. They have a history of Herpes Zoster infection on the same side of their face a few weeks ago. On examination, you notice decreased visual acuity and inflammation in the eye. Which of the following complications of Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus is the patient most unlikely experiencing?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Keratoconjunctivitis sicca

  • Keratoconjunctivitis sicca, also known as dry eye syndrome, is not a common complication of Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus.
  • The other options (A, C, and D) are potential complications of Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus:

Option A. Keratitis: Inflammation of the cornea.

 

Option C. Uveitis: Inflammation of the uvea, the middle layer of the eye.

 

Option D. Necrotising retinitis: A severe inflammation of the retina.

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 12 weeks of gestation comes to the antenatal clinic for nutritional advice. Her BMI is 27. She is curious to know, for her BMI, what should her average weight gain in her pregnancy be?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 7-11 kg

 

IDEAL WEIGHT GAIN IN PREGNANCY

 

 

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no. 483

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department with a fever of 102°F and altered sensorium. Upon examination, you notice a petechial rash on the patient's arms and legs. You suspect meningococcal septicaemia. Which of the following antibiotics is recommended as the first-line empiric therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ceftriaxone

  • Meningococcal septicaemia is a medical emergency that requires prompt antibiotic therapy.
  • Empiric therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone is recommended as the first-line treatment for suspected meningococcal septicaemia.
  • Penicillin G is an alternative option but is less commonly used due to increasing resistance.
  • Piperacillin-tazobactam and cotrimoxazole are not recommended as first-line treatments for meningococcal septicemia.
  • Definitive therapy should be based on culture and susceptibility results.

DOC for empirical therapy of meningitis:

 

 

 

Note:

  • Vancomycin is given to cover gram positive bacteria like Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus (including MRSA).
  • Ampicillin is given to cover Listeria.
  • Meropenem is given to cover gram negative bacteria.
  • Cefotaxime can be used in place of ceftriaxone.
  • Cefepime can be used in place of meropenem.

choices.text: Benson and Durfee

questions.text: A 39-year-old G2P1 presents at 18 weeks 5 days for her routine targeted fetal anomaly ultrasound. The fetal anatomy appears normal, but the cervical length is 15mm. Despite being counselled that there is no clear proven benefit for the same; the patient insisted on a cervical cerclage. What type of cerclage would you prefer at this gestational age?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. McDonald

 

TYPES OF CERCLAGES

  • Transvaginal cervical cerclage:
    • McDonald (purse string suture around the cervix): Most commonly performed and usually the initial cerclage of choice.
    • Shirodkar (cerclage after pushing the bladder up so the suture placement is more cephalad I.e., nearer to the os)
  • Transabdominal cerclage:
    • Can be performed before pregnancy (ideal) or during pregnancy
    • Physiologically this suture is physiologically closest to the internal os
    • Indicated in transvaginal route failures
    • Delivery is always by cesarean
    • If done by laparotomy; it is called as Benson and Durfee cerclage

 

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no. 539

choices.text: Wide local resection with bilateral inguinal node dissection
Combined radiation therapy and chemotherapy

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman sees blood on the toilet paper. Her doctor notes the presence of an excoriated bleeding, 2.8-cm mass at the anus. Biopsy confirms the clinical suspicion of anal cancer. In planning the management of a 2.8-cm epidermoid carcinoma of the anus, which of the following is the best initial management strategy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Combined radiation therapy and chemotherapy

  • Epidermoid cancers of the anal canal metastasize to inguinal nodes as well as to the perirectal and mesenteric nodes.
  • The results of local radical surgery have been disappointing.
  • Combined external radiation with synchronous chemotherapy (fluorouracil and mitomycin), also known as the Nigro protocol, has been used as the standard treatment of the disease, whereas radical surgical approaches are now generally reserved for treatment failures and recurrences.

choices.text: Bilateral interstitial infiltrates
Symptom onset within a week
No cardiac failure on echocardiography

questions.text: According to the Berlin definition, moderate ARDS is characterized by all, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. PaO2/FiO2 ratio = 200-300 mm/Hg

 

2012 BERLIN DEFINITION

  1. Onset within 7 days after a known clinical insult or new or worsening respiratory symptoms.
  2. B/L opacities (Alveolar/Interstitial that are "consistent with pulmonary edema" on chest radiographs or chest CT)
  3. Minimum PEEP setting or CPAP, 5 cm of water.
  • PaO2:FiO2 assessed on invasive mechanical ventilation (CPAP criterion used for the diagnosis of mild ARDS)

Categorization of ARDS severity:

  • Mild: 200-300
  • Moderate: 100-200
  • Severe: <100
  • In resource limited settings, Kigali Modifications was proposed (2016).
    1.  

A. Bilateral opacities could be documented by either ultrasonography or chest radiograph.

 

B. Oxygenation criteria: pulse oximetry oxygen saturation (SpO2)/FiO2 ratio ≤ 315 without the requirement for PEEP.

 

Option B, C, D are true statements in ARDS.

 

 

Ref: Harrison, Respiratory Failure, Chapter-301

choices.text: Review USG after 2 weeks
Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks
ECV at 36 weeks
Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 presents at 35 weeks. She has no complaints and is appreciating fetal movements well. She had a previous classical cesarean at 25 weeks for eclampsia and severe FGR. She is currently on low dose aspirin and prenatal vitamins. On examination, the uterus is SFH is 38 cm and FHR is 140 bpm. An ultrasound reveals a single live fetus in breech presentation, placenta posterior and amniotic fluid normal. The patient desires a vaginal delivery. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks

  • The next step in the management of this pregnancy with breech presentation and a history of previous classical cesarean delivery is a cesarean section at 37 weeks.
  • A classical cesarean section is an ABSOLUTE CONTRA-INDICATION to a vaginal delivery hence there is no point doing an ECV and an elective cesarean should be planned at 37 weeks and patient should be counseled that a vaginal delivery is NOT SAFE in her
  • An ECV is also relatively contra-indicated if the patient has a previous scarred uterus
  • The risk of uterine rupture following a classical cesarean is very high (4-9%) compared with a previous lower segment cesarean (0.2-1%)

 

 

Ref: William Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no. 1439

choices.text: Hydatid of Morgagni

questions.text: The sonographic “tip of the iceberg” sign corresponds to the site within a mature cystic teratoma where the most varied tissue types, such as hair and fatty secretions, are found. Pathologically, what is the name of this area?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rokitansky protuberance

  • A Rokitansky nodule or dermoid plug refers to a solid protuberance projecting from an ovarian cyst in the context of mature cystic teratoma.
  • It often contains calcific, dental, adipose, hair, and/or sebaceous components. 
  • This region has the highest propensity to undergo malignant transformation.

Other options

  • Homunculus: This is a rare form of a teratoma that resembles a malformed fetus.
  • Struma ovarii: Struma ovarii is a variant of dermoid tumors of the ovary in which thyroid tissue components are the major constituent. Thyroid tissue is observed not uncommonly in 5-15% of dermoid tumors, but to qualify as a struma ovarii tumor the thyroid proportion must comprise more than 50% of the overall tissue.
  • Hydatid of Morgagni: Hydatids of Morgagni are benign, pedunculated, cystic structures arising from Müllerian vestiges below the fallopian tube near the fimbria. They usually are of no clinical significance unless the pedicle becomes twisted, and infarction occurs.

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition, Page no. 293

questions.text: Low serum copper levels attributed to ATP7A gene is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Menke’s disease

  • ATP7A gene mutation is associated with reduced intestinal absorption of copper leading to low S. Copper levels.
  • Children die within 5 years.
  • MCC: CVS – Aneurysmal dissection/Cardiac rupture

  • Option A, B, D are not involved with ATP7A mutation.
  • ATP7B mutations cause Wilson's disease.

choices.text: It can be reduced by matching
It is associated individually with both cause and effect
It is distributed equally in both study and control groups
It is associated with the exposure of the study

questions.text: All of the following statements are true for confounding factor except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is distributed equally in both study and control groups

  • Confounding factor: Any factor associated with both exposure and outcome, and has an independent effect in causation of outcome is a confounder.
  • It is found unequally distributed between the study and control groups
  • Confounding can be removed by:
    1. Matching → MC used/simplest method
    2. Randomisation → 2nd Best Method
    3. Restriction
    4. Stratification
    5. Statistical Modelling/Multivariate analysis (MVA)
    6. Stratified Randomization → Overall Best Method

choices.text: Optic nerve sheath meningioma
Optic nerve glioma

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a gradual loss of visual acuity in the right eye. MRI is shown here. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Optic nerve sheath meningioma

  • The given clinical scenario presenting with manifestations like gradual loss of visual acuity in the right eye and CT showing thickening of the optic nerve sheath complex with a tram track appearance point towards the diagnosis of optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram-track appearance with ON seen separately: ON meningioma

  • Fusiform mass involving the optic nerve: ON Glioma

  • Retinoblastoma: A child with intra-ocular mass with calcification on CT

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No. 742

choices.text: Cyst wall ablation
Fulguration of endometrioma

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with subfertility and a 7 cm endometrioma. For surgical treatment of endometriomas, which of the following approaches is superior?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cystectomy

  • Endometriomas or chocolate cysts are best treated surgically by laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy.
  • This means stripping the cyst wall from the overlying normal ovarian tissue to prevent it from recurring.

 

 

Ref: Dc Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition, Page no. 312

choices.text: Patient hears better when there is ear discharge than when there is no discharge
Phase differential gets cancelled in case of dry perforation
In presence of discharge, sound waves hitting on round window are shielded by discharge

questions.text: What is round window shielding effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

  • Patient hears better when there is ear discharge than when there is no discharge
  • Phase differential gets cancelled in case of dry perforation
  • In presence of discharge, sound waves hitting on round window are shielded by discharge

choices.text: Only abductor is lateral cricoarytenoid
Recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all intrinsic muscles of larynx
Sensory supply to the larynx is by superior laryngeal nerve only
False vocal cord is formed by the lower border of aryepiglottic fold

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. False vocal cord is formed by the lower border of aryepiglottic fold

  • Only abductor is posterior cricoarytenoid.
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all intrinsic muscles of larynx except cricothyroid.
  • Cricothyroid is supplied by external branch of superior laryngeal nerve.
  • Both superior and recurrent laryngeal nerves form sensory supply in upper and lower segments (above and below the level of vocal cords) respectively.
  • The thickened lower border of the aryepiglottic fold is called as false vocal cord.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy. Which investigation should be performed next to help you diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ANCA

  • Features are suggestive of small vessel vasculitis.

Option B. RA factor can be elevated in Mixed cryoglobulinemia that can have above presentations however is not very diagnostic.

 

Option C. Neuropathy is not common and is very rare with chronic Hepatitis B.

 

Option D. DIF is not diagnostic.

questions.text: In a patient with gastrointestinal symptoms, the dysfunction of which cellular structure, associated with the transmembrane protein Claudin, could potentially lead to altered permeability and paracellular transport?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tight junctions                                            

  • Three major families of transmembrane proteins that contribute to the tight junctions – Occludin, Junctional adhesion molecules, Claudins.
  • These transmembrane proteins aid in establishing a specialized connection between adjacent epithelial cells (cell to cell contact).
  • Occludins are the first integral tight junction protein to be discovered.
  • Tight junctions are crucial in regulating the permeability (based on size and charge) of the epithelial layer (paracellular pathway).
  • Dysfunction of tight junctions, including Claudin proteins, can lead to increased paracellular transport, causing issues such as chronic diarrhea and malabsorption.

questions.text: The observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match the ECG findings of a patient. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

 

 

  • Stress cardiomyopathy commonly affects Women (post-menopausal) > men predominantly due to emotional > physical stress.
  • Neurogenic myocardial stunning occurs leading to heart failure.
  • Beta-2 (Gs stimulation) at base and B2 (Gi) activation leads to hypercontractility at the base & apical ballooning giving a typical Takotsubo appearance.
  • ECG mimics ACS, RWMA not corresponding to single artery territory, normal CAG with Mild troponin elevation are clues to takotsubo.
  • Treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors if non-responsive. Carries good prognosis.

Option B. Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes diastolic dysfunction on but NOT significant ECG changes

 

Option C. Brugada syndrome is a channelopathy caused due LOF (loss of function) mutation of cardiac SCN5a (Sodium channel) resulting in transmural voltage difference between endocardium-epicardium causing ventricular arrhythmias which initially affects the RV Myocardium

 

  • Option D. Tamponade occurs due to rapid accumulation of fluid/blood in the pericardium producing the characteristic Beck triad (↑ JVP, ↓ Heart sounds, ↓ BP).

questions.text: Which type of anaemia is characterized by the destruction of red blood cells at a rate faster than the body can replace them?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aplastic anaemia

  • Aplastic anaemia is characterized by the destruction of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets at a rate faster than the body can replace them. This condition is typically due to damage to the bone marrow, where blood cells are produced, and can result in a decreased number of red blood cells, leading to anaemia.

 

Option A. Incorrect. Iron-deficiency anemia is primarily caused by a lack of iron in the body, which is essential for red blood cell production. While it can result in a decreased number of red blood cells, it is not primarily characterized by the destruction of red blood cells.

 

Option B. Incorrect. Sickle cell anemia is caused by a genetic mutation affecting haemoglobin, leading to the production of abnormal haemoglobin S and the characteristic "sickle" shape of red blood cells. While these cells can become rigid and break more easily, the anemia is primarily caused by the abnormal haemoglobin, not the rapid destruction of red blood cells.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Pernicious anemia is characterized by a deficiency in vitamin B12 absorption due to a lack of intrinsic factor, a substance needed for vitamin B12 absorption. It is not primarily characterized by the destruction of red blood cells.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of the right side of the face with loss of pain and temperature. Additionally, he experienced a loss of pain and temperature sensation in their left leg. The probable location of the lesion is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lateral pons

  • The above clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral pontine syndrome which occurs due to a lesion located at lateral pons.

 

 

STROKE SYMPTOMS

 

Rule of 4’s:

  1. 4 cranial nerves originate above pons (2 in midbrain), 4 in pons, 4 in medulla
  2. 4 midline cranial nerves (CN 3, 4, 6, 12) (divide equally into 12 except 1 and 2)
  3. 4 Midline structures that begin with M
    • Motor pathway (aka corticospinal tract)
    • Medial lemniscus
    • Medial longitudinal fasciculus
    • Medial cranial nerves (CN 3, 4, 6, 12)
       
  4.  4 structures to the Side that begin with S
    • Spinocerebellar pathway (ipsilateral ataxia of arm and leg)
    • Spinothalamic pathway
    • Sensory portion of CN V
    • Sympathetic pathway

choices.text: Its diameter is less than left coronary artery
It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conus artery is its first branch

questions.text: All of the following are true about the right coronary artery except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch

  • The right coronary artery does not give rise to the circumflex coronary artery.
  • The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery that supplies the right bundle branch exclusively.
  • Originating from the right coronary sinus of the ascending aorta, the right coronary artery has a smaller diameter compared to the left coronary artery.
  • It courses anteriorly and descends perpendicularly along the coronary sulcus, situated between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
  • Upon reaching the inferior border, it takes a posterior turn and persists along the sulcus onto the diaphragmatic surface and base of the heart.

 

 

Branches of right coronary artery:

  • Atrial branches are anterior, posterior and lateral. One of the anterior atrial branches is called SA nodal artery.
  • Right conus artery: it is usually the first branch. It forms an arterial circle around pulmonary trunk with a similar branch from the left coronary artery. The circle is called ‘annulus of Vieussen’s’.
  • Ventricular branches are as anterior and posterior groups.
  • Right marginal artery
  • Posterior interventricular branch

questions.text: What percentage of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 68%

  • Approximately 68% of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve.
  • In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,
    1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve
    2. Mean = Median = Mode → Known as coincidence
    3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1
    4. Mean ± 1SD → Covers 68% value [68.3%]
    5. Mean ± 2SD → Covers 95% value [95.4%]
    6. Mean ± 3SD → Covers 99% value [99.7%]

choices.text: The statement A is true, the statement B is false
The statement A is false, the statement B is true
Both the statements A and B are true
Both the statements A and B are false

questions.text:
Statement A: The C type nerve fibers have the lowest conduction velocity compared with all other types of nerve fibers.

 

Statement B: The B type nerve fibers have a conduction velocity of 10 m/s.

 

Which of the following is right regarding these two statements?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both the statements A and B are true

  • The type C nerve fibers have the lowest conduction velocity among the different types of nerve fibers.
  • The conduction velocity of dorsal root C nerve fibers (sensory) will be around 0.5-2 m/s and that of sympathetic C fibers will be around 0.7-2.3 m/s.
  • The conduction velocity of B type nerve fibers will be in the range of 3-15 m/s (here, mentioned as 10 m/s).
  • Different types of nerve fibers are:

questions.text: In breastfeeding medicine, which hormone plays a key role in the ejection of milk from the alveoli into the ducts for infant consumption?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oxytocin

  • Oxytocin plays a crucial role in the milk ejection reflex (let-down reflex).
  • When a baby suckles at the breast, the release of oxytocin causes the muscles surrounding the milk-filled alveoli to contract, pushing milk into the ducts and allowing the infant to access it.

Option A. Incorrect. Prolactin is responsible for milk production in the mammary glands but not for milk ejection. It stimulates the alveoli to produce milk.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Estrogen does not directly influence milk ejection. It plays a role in breast development during pregnancy but decreases before lactation begins.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Progesterone is involved in preparing the breast tissue for milk production during pregnancy but is not the primary hormone responsible for milk ejection.

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Brodie’s abscess

 

BRODIE’S ABSCESS

  • It is a long standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone (long standing because of strong defense mechanism of body).
  • Seen in immunocompetent host.
  • It usually involves long bones (metaphysis or diaphysis); e.g., Upper end of tibia.
  • Classical Brodie’s abscess looks like a small walled off (sclerotic margins) cavity in bone with little or no periosteal reaction.
  • Usual isolated organism is Staphylococcus aureus (although most cultures are negative).
  • Treatment: Trial of injectable antibiotics is given; if it fails, curettage of the cavity is carried out.

questions.text: A small child was playing with her maid where she rotated him by holding from arms. Immediately after, the child started crying. On examination, her arm was pronated. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pulled elbow

  • History of traction on elbow with forearm pronated is classical of pulled elbow.

Pulled Elbow/Nurse Maid’s Elbow:

  • It is subluxation of radial head or more accurately subluxation of the annular (orbicular) ligament which slips up over the head of radius into the radio-capitellar joint.

  • Mechanism of Injury: Traction to elbow

Clinical Features:

  • Maximum incidence in 1-4 years age group.
  • The child holds the elbow in slight flexion with the forearm pronated.
  • X-rays are normal.

Treatment:

  • Reduced by flexing the elbow to 90° and rapidly and firmly rotating the forearm into full supination on outdoor basis without anesthesia. Immobilization is not necessary.
  • Supination is a gravity assisted movement and pulled elbow may be reduced spontaneously by gravity, but this may take time.

Her 33-year-old mother subsequently developed arthralgia followed by painful arthritis with swelling in the small joints of both hands. questions.text: An elderly male who is a known smoker, presented with persistent coughing, substantial weight loss, and noticeable fatigue. His blood test indicates elevated serum calcium levels. A lung biopsy was conducted, revealing the presence of oversized, unusual cells displaying hyperchromasia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Squamous cell carcinoma

  • According to given clinical scenario, most likely diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

SQUAMOUS CELL CANCER

  • Histological hallmark: Keratin: Intercellular bridge or keratin pearls present; IHC shows p40+; p 63+
  • 2nd M/C carcinoma in India
  • More common in males, smokers
  • Central location near hilum
  • Associated with Cavitation
  • Good prognosis as late metastasis
  • Tumor cells secrete PTH relate peptide causing to hypercalcemia

The image given below shows keratin pearls seen in squamous cell carcinomas.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Large cell neuroendocrine tumor:

  • Type of large cell cancer
  • Large cell seen; Diagnosis of Exclusion
  • Non-smokers, peripheral location
  • Tumor cells secrete estrogen (gynecomastia)

Option B. Small cell carcinoma:

  • Histological hallmark: Small cells with Neurosecretory granules, Azzopardi effect
  • IHC shows synaptophysin +; Chromogranin +; CD 56 +, BCL2 +
  • Males, smoker, central in location
  • Best response to chemotherapy and radiotherapy but still has WORST prognosis (aggressive and early metastasis to CNS)
  • Maximum paraneoplastic syndromes (ACTH causing Cushing syndrome and ADH causing SIADH (hyponatramia), Calcitonin (hypocalcemia)

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma:

  • IHC markers are Napsin A, TTF1, SP-A1
  • Overall most common lung cancer
  • More in females and non-smokers
  • Peripheral in location; scar cancer
  • Asbestos is a risk factor
  • Tumor cells secrete mucin (thrombophlebitis) and clubbing
  • Adenocarcinoma in situ may cause suffocation

questions.text: The joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib with 7th rib is a:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Synovial joint

  • The interchondral joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib with the 7th rib is a synovial joint.
  • Joints in the thoracic cavity are of the following types:
    • Synarthrosis: A fibrous band of tissue connects the structures. E.g., 1st sternocostal joint
    • Synchondrosis: primary cartilaginous joints. E.g., costochondral joints
    • Symphysis: secondary cartilaginous joints. E.g., manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints
    • Synovial joints: the presence of these help the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.,
      • Interchondral joint
      • Sternocostal joint
      • Costovertebral joint
      • Costotransverse joint

questions.text: A 30-year-old male met with an accident, when investigated he was not able to identify the persons close to him. This condition can be described as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prosopagnosia

  • In the cerebral cortex, the storage and recognition of faces will be represented in the inferior part of the right temporal lobe (right-handed persons) and the lesion to this area will result in prosopagnosia.
  • Prosopagnosia is the inability to identify faces (especially familiar faces).

  • Astereognosis is the inability to identify the objects by tactile sensations (touch).
  • Dysdiadochokinesia is the inability to execute rapid alternating movements (seen in cerebellar lesions).
  • Akinetopsia can be defined as the inability to perceive moving objects.

questions.text: Coagulation profile monitoring is needed in therapy with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lepirudin

  • Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that is used in multiple doses and produces unpredictable effects, that has the most serious side effect of bleeding. Therefore, it requires monitoring by aPTT.
  • Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor, Enoxaparin is a LMWH that acts by inhibiting factor Xa and factor IIa, whereas Fondaparinux acts only by inhibiting factor Xa only. These drugs routinely do not require monitoring.

questions.text: Below is the X-ray image of a 70-year-old male patient. All clinical examinations, as well as hematological and urinary tests, yielded normal results. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Langerhans cell histiocytosis

  • The history and the provided imaging, which shows a single punched-out lytic lesion without a sclerotic rim and with a beveled edge look, point to Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
  • Multiple myeloma - A diagnosis of multiple myeloma is made by the typical triad of symptoms, which includes a marrow plasmacytosis of more than 10%, radiologic evidence of lytic bone lesions, and the presence of serum and/or urine M component.
  • CRAB criteria for MM:
    • Hypercalcemia: serum calcium >11mg/dl
    • Renal Insufficiency: serum creatinine >2 mg/dl or creatinine clearance <40 ml/min
    • Anemia: Hb <10 g/dl
    • Lytic bone lesions

  • Primary hyperparathyroidism: Patients with this condition have high levels of the parathyroid hormone, as well as hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypercalciuria

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who is 20 weeks pregnant, presents to the clinic for a routine prenatal visit. Her blood pressure readings have consistently been elevated over her past two appointments. The medical team is considering antihypertensive medication options that are safe to use during pregnancy. Which of the following antihypertensive are not used in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Propranolol

  • Non-selective Beta blockers like propranolol are generally not recommended for use in pregnancy for hypertension because of potential risks to the fetus, including intrauterine growth restriction and neonatal bradycardia. However, Labetalol is a third-generation beta blocker (with additional vasodilatory property) and is drug of choice for hypertension in pregnancy.

choices.text: IL-1 receptor antagonist
IL-2 receptor antagonist

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient has recently undergone renal transplantation. To minimize the risk of transplant rejection, the medical team is considering the use of an immunosuppressive agent that specifically targets T-cell activation without causing generalized immunosuppression. Among the options, they are discussing basiliximab. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of basiliximab?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. IL-2 receptor antagonist

  • Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody that has a high affinity to IL-2 Receptors and exerts an antagonistic effect on it.
  • IL-2 receptor is also called CD-25, so basiliximab is an anti-CD25 antibody.

Other options:

  • IL-1 receptor antagonist, such as anakinra, is used primarily in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis but is not specifically targeted for transplant rejection.
  • Anti-CD3 antibody targets CD3 on the surface of T cells and leads to broad immunosuppression. It is not usually the first choice for preventing rejection due to its extensive immunosuppressive effects.
  • Basiliximab is an IL-2 receptor antagonist that specifically blocks the IL-2 receptor on the surface of activated T cells, effectively preventing T-cell activation and proliferation. It is commonly used to prevent acute rejection in kidney transplantation.
  • TNF inhibitors like infliximab or etanercept are mainly used in autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and are not typically used for preventing organ transplant rejection.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with complaints of facial swelling, frothy urine, and elevated blood pressure. He reports a previous hepatitis B infection. Microscopic examination of the urine reveals the presence of small amounts of blood. The kidney biopsy's histopathological image displays a characteristic spike and dome pattern. What is the diagnosis for this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Membranous nephropathy

  • Membranous Nephropathy is the most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in elderly.

 

 

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Haematuria is Not seen.

 

Biopsy findings in this condition are as follows:

  • Light microscopy: glomeruli appear normal (hence called 'minimal change')
  • Electron microscopy: diffuse effacement of foot processes of visceral epithelial cells (podocytopathy)

Option C. FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. Haematuria and Subepithelial deposits are NOT seen.

 

Option D: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is characterized by the sudden onset of gross haematuria, oedema, hypertension, renal insufficiency, on Electron microscopy, spike and dome pattern is not seen.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. Examination of a duodenal biopsy from this patient revealed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and the presence of CD8+ cells within the lamina propria. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Celiac disease

  • The clinical presentation and histopathological findings point to celiac disease.
  • Celiac disease is sometimes referred to as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. In genetically predisposed individuals, it is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the consumption of gluten-containing cereals such as Barley, Rye, Oat & Wheat (BROW).
  • Almost all celiac disease patients have the class II HLADQ2 or HLA-DQ8 allele.
  • Histopathology: Increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy characterize the histopathology.

  • Prior to biopsy, non-invasive serologic tests are usually performed. The presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase or IgA or IgG antibodies to deamidated gliadin is the most sensitive test. Anti-endomysial antibodies are more specific than other antibodies but less sensitive.
  • Clinical features:
    • Malabsorption syndrome with chronic refractory anemia, chronic diarrhea, bloating, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss. A characteristic itchy, blistering skin lesion, dermatitis herpetiformis, can be present in as many as 10% of patients, and the incidence of lymphocytic gastritis and lymphocytic colitis is also increased.
    • Enteropathy associated T cell lymphoma.
    • Small intestinal adenocarcinoma.
       
  • Treatment: Gluten free diet results in symptomatic improvement for most patients, but a gluten-free diet may also reduce the risk of long-term complications including anemia, female infertility, osteoporosis, and cancer.
  • Dapsone for dermatitis herpetiformis.

Option A. Environmental enteropathy/tropical sprue is seen in tropical areas with poor sanitation. It is believed to be caused by one or more infectious agents that respond to antibiotics. Mucosa shows variable villous atrophy. Folic acid and B12 deficiency is common.

 

Option C. Whipple's disease is a multisystemic disease caused by T. whipplei. Small intestinal biopsy shows PAS-positive macrophages.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with Stellate granuloma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sub-acute regional lymphadenitis 

  • Stellate granuloma is seen in cat-scratch disease. It is also called as subacute regional lymphadenitis.
  • It is a bacterial infection caused by Bartonella henselae. Acquired following contact with infected animals (commonly cats).
  • Regional lymph nodes demonstrate:
    • Follicular hyperplasia with circumscribed central stellate necrosis with neutrophils
    • Surrounded by palisading histiocytes (suppurative granulomas)
    • Sinuses packed with monoctoid B cells
    • Usually, there are no perifollicular and intrafollicular epithelioid cells

questions.text: In a well-designed cancer study, comparable rates of remission were achieved for both a new treatment (33.2%) and the conventional treatment (32.2%). The corresponding p-value was recorded as 0.04. Which of the following statements is true regarding the study?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment

  • A p-value of 0.04 (< 0.05) indicates that the results are statistically significant and there is evidence to suggest that the new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment.
  • Although the difference in remission rates is small, it is still statistically significant, which means that the new treatment may have some clinical benefits compared to the usual treatment.

choices.text: It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of coronary artery disease is being evaluated in the cardiology clinic. The cardiologist is considering to add a new antiplatelet agent to his treatment regimen to reduce the risk of stent thrombosis. Prasugrel is one of the options under consideration. Which of the following statements is true about prasugrel?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is a pro-drug

  • Prasugrel is a prodrug that is metabolized by the liver to its active metabolite, which is an inhibitor of P2Y12 ADP platelet receptors.
  • This active metabolite irreversibly inhibits platelet aggregation, making prasugrel a potent antiplatelet agent.

Option A is incorrect because prasugrel is not a P2Y12 agonist but rather an antagonist.

 

Option B is incorrect because prasugrel is actually more potent than clopidogrel.

 

Option D is incorrect because omeprazole can interfere with the activation of prasugrel to its active metabolite, reducing its antiplatelet effect.

choices.text: Local excision and topical (intravesicular) chemotherapy

questions.text: A 60-year-old man sees a urologist for what he describes as bloody urine. A urine sample is positive for cytologic evidence of malignancy. Cystoscopy confirms the presence of superficial transitional cell carcinoma. Which of the following is the recommended treatment for stage A (superficial and submucosal) transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Local excision and topical (intravesicular) chemotherapy

  • Ninety percent of bladder cancers are of transitional cell origin.
  • It is most prevalent among men with a history of heavy smoking and is usually multifocal and superficial, even when recurrent.
  • When the disease is still superficial, transurethral resection of visible lesions and intravesicular chemotherapy are most often recommended.
  • More radical surgical resection, systemic chemotherapy, and radiation are reserved for advanced stages of the disease.

questions.text: Identify the MRI sequence?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Susceptibility weighted image

  • Susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI) is an MRI sequence that is particularly sensitive to compounds which distort the local magnetic field and as such make it useful in detecting blood products, calcium, etc.
  • SWI is a type of gradient-echo MRI sequence. Compounds that have paramagnetic, diamagnetic, and ferromagnetic properties all interact with the local magnetic field distorting it and thus altering the phase of local tissue which, in turn, results in a change of signal. 
  • Paramagnetic compounds include deoxyhemoglobin, ferritin and hemosiderin. 
  • Diamagnetic compounds include bone minerals and dystrophic calcifications.

questions.text: Sequence of angles of head movements turned sequentially stepwise in Epley manoeuvre:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 45 degree → 30 degree → 90 degree → 90 degree

 

  • The Epley manoeuvre is a procedure used to treat benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), a condition characterized by sudden, brief episodes of dizziness or vertigo that occur when you move your head in certain ways.
  • BPPV is believed to be caused by tiny crystals (otoconia) in the inner ear that have become dislodged and moved into the semicircular canals, where they interfere with the normal fluid movement that these canals use to sense head motion.
  • Epley Maneuver Step-by-Step:
    • For Right Ear BPPV:
      1. Starting Position: Sit up on a bed, with your legs flat on the bed, and turn your head 45⁰ to the right.
      2. First Movement: Quickly lie down on your back, keeping your head turned 45⁰ to the right and a pillow should be under your shoulders, allowing your head to be slightly tilted backward (hanging off the bed a bit – 30⁰). Hold this position for 30 seconds to a minute or until the vertigo subsides.
      3. Second Movement: Without raising your head, turn it 90⁰ to the left (so that it is 45⁰ to the left relative to your body), and hold this position for 30 seconds to a minute.
      4. Third Movement: Keeping your head turned, roll your body onto your left side (you will now be looking downward) and hold this position for 30 seconds to a minute.
      5. Final Movement: Slowly sit up, keeping your head turned in the direction it was in during the last step, then slowly return your head to the centre/front position.
         
    • For Left Ear BPPV: The procedure is the same but mirrored; you would start by turning your head 45⁰ to the left, and follow through with the opposite movements described above.

choices.text: Henoch Schonlein Purpura

questions.text: A 36-months-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of her hands and feet since past 5 days. The child presents with peeling skin rash, swelling in the hands and feet, redness of the palms and soles, oral redness, and enlarged cervical lymph nodes. What is the probable medical condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Kawasaki disease

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.
  • Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.
  • Kawasaki Disease Mnemonic:

CRASH & Burn

  • Conjunctivitis (non-purulent)
  • Rash
  • Adenopathy (cervical and commonly unilateral)
  • Strawberry tongue
  • Hands (palmar erythema/swelling)
  • Burn (fever lasting at least 5 days or more)
  • The disease is usually self-limiting.
  • In some cases, the disease may involve coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction.
  • Treatment: Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura is an acute, systemic, immune complex-mediated, leukocytoclastic vasculitis. It is characterized by a clinical triad of palpable purpura (without thrombocytopenia), abdominal pain, and arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following acts as an opsonin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C3b

  • C3b functions as an opsonin.
  • Opsonization: The process of coating a foreign particle and preparing it for phagocytosis. The substances involved in this process are called opsonins.
  • Include:
    • Mannose-binding lectin
    • IgM and Fc receptor of IgG
    • CRP
    • Fibrinogen
    • C3b, C4b, C5b

choices.text: Trinucleotide mutation in FMR-1 gene
Large everted ears

questions.text: All of the following statements are true for fragile X syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Micro-orchidism

  • Macro-orchidism (large testicles) are seen in fragile X syndrome, not micro-orchidism.
  • Fragile X syndrome is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome.
  • This expansion leads to a deficiency in the FMRP protein, which is important for neural development and function.
  • Males with fragile X syndrome often have macro-orchidism, which can be observed during childhood and becomes more apparent during puberty.
  • Other physical features of fragile X syndrome may include a long and narrow face, prominent forehead and chin, and large ears that are often everted.
  • Intellectual disability and behavioral problems are also common features of the syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following induces B-cells to produce IgE?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. IL-4

  • IL-4 stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE secreting plasma cells.
  • IL-4 is a cytokine that plays a crucial role in promoting B-cell differentiation and class switching to produce IgE antibodies. It is primarily produced by T-helper 2 (Th2) cells and stimulates B-cells to undergo isotype switching, leading to the production of IgE instead of other antibody isotypes, such as IgG or IgM.
  • IL-2 (A), IL-1 (C), and IL-6 (D) are cytokines that have various roles in immune responses, but they are not directly involved in the induction of B-cells to produce IgE. IL-2 plays a role in T-cell proliferation and activation, IL-1 is involved in inflammation and immune responses, and IL-6 is important for inflammation and hematopoiesis.

choices.text: Chronic myeloid leukemia

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department complaining of fatigue, weariness, and swelling in the neck's lymph nodes. Initial blood tests, including total lymphocyte count (TLC) and differential lymphocyte count (DLC), showed normal results with no signs of immature cells. Subsequently, a lymph node biopsy was conducted, revealing a diffuse disruption of the lymph node structure, atypical cells characterized by an indented nucleus and prominent nucleolus. Immunohistochemical staining displayed positivity for CD10 and BCL2. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Follicular lymphoma

  • The clinical scenario presented here, which includes fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy with CD10 positive BCL2 positive cells, strongly suggests follicular lymphoma.
  • The most common type of indolent NHL is follicular lymphoma. It usually appears in middle age and affects both men and women equally. The tumour is most likely caused by germinal center B cells.
  • A (14;18) translocation between the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 locus on chromosome 18 is the hallmark of follicular lymphoma.
  • Histologically, at low magnification, a predominantly nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern is observed in involved lymph nodes.
  • Two principal cell types are present in varying proportions:
      1.  
  1. Small cells with irregular or cleaved nuclear contours and scant cytoplasm, referred to as centrocytes (small cleaved cells)
  2. Larger cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm, referred to as centroblasts.
  • Immunophenotyping: The neoplastic cells closely resemble normal germinal center B cells, expressing CD19, CD20, CD10, surface Ig, and BCL6. CD5 is not expressed. BCL2 is expressed in more than 90% of cases.

Rapid filling phase

questions.solution:
Ans. B. Rapid filling phase

 

MECHANISMS OF DIFFERENT HEART SOUNDS

questions.text: According to Biomedical Waste Management guidelines, cytotoxic and expired medications are appropriately discarded by:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Incineration

  • Expired and cytotoxic drugs should be disposed of using specific methods, such as incineration, encapsulation, or plasma pyrolysis, and should be returned to the manufacturer if possible.
  • Other medications can also be disposed of using similar methods.
  • The use of yellow bags is common for hazardous waste to ensure proper handling and disposal by trained personnel.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve fibers is primarily responsible for the motor supply to the intrafusal muscle fibers within the muscle spindle, playing a crucial role in proprioceptive function?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gamma

  • Gamma type of nerve fibers are involved in the motor supply to the intrafusal muscle fibers.
  • The Aα (alpha motor neurons) fibers supply the extrafusal muscle fibers, whereas Aɣ (gamma motor neurons) fibers supply the intrafusal muscle fibers (motor to muscle spindle).

  • The extrafusal muscle fibers are the major contractile units involved in muscle contraction and the intrafusal muscle fibers are located parallel to these fibers
  • The Aβ (beta) fibers are associated with touch and pressure sensations, whereas Aδ (delta) fibers are associated with pain and temperature sensations

questions.text: During a yawn, a student experienced a jaw locking incident. Identify the muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lateral pterygoid

  • The muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint is the lateral pterygoid.

  • All Innervated by CN V3

questions.text: An individual who has been regularly exposed to benzene due to his occupation, is now presenting with symptoms such as recurrent infections, fatigue, unexplained weight loss, and a rise in temperature during the evening. This sustained exposure to benzene is associated with an increased susceptibility to which type of cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Leukemia

  • Benzene exposure at work increases the risk of developing leukemia. The clinical history of repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening temperature rise with benzene exposure points to leukemia.
  • Hepatic CYP2E1 converts benzene to an epoxide. The epoxide and other metabolites disrupt bone marrow progenitor cell differentiation, resulting in marrow aplasia and acute myeloid leukemia.
  • Acute myeloid leukemia (AML), acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL), chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), multiple myeloma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma have all been linked to benzene exposure.

Other options:

 

Option B. Lung cancer: Exposure to arsenic and its compounds, asbestos, beryllium and its compounds, chromium compounds, nickel compounds, radon, and its decay products can cause lung cancer.

 

Option C. Bladder cancer: Exposure to aryl amines, particularly 2-naphthylamine and related compounds, cyclophosphamide, cigarette smoking, irradiation can cause bladder cancer.

 

Option D. Skin cancer: Exposure to UV rays, arsenic, and its compounds can cause skin cancer.

questions.text: A patient was undergoing clinical evaluation during which the marked structure was stimulated. Which of the following nerves was being tested?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IX

  • The structure marked is uvula.
  • The sensory supply to the uvula is by the glossopharyngeal nerve and it is tested in this case.

 

Pharyngeal plexus:

  • The nerve supply to the pharynx is primarily provided by the pharyngeal plexus.
  • The pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve combine to form it.
  • It also receives input from the superior cervical ganglion.
  • The motor supply is provided by the vagus nerve, and the sensory supply is provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male Prakash presents to his primary care physician Dr. Dileep with complaints of fatigue, easy bruising, and night sweats. On physical examination, splenomegaly is noted. He is referred to Cerebellum Pathology Lab where the complete blood count reveals an elevated white blood cell count with a left shift, increased basophils, and increased myeloid cells. She reports sudden onset of worsening symptoms for last 5 days. Which of the following is a criterion for the diagnosis of accelerated phase of chronic myeloid leukemia according to WHO 2017 criteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Additional clonal chromosomal abnormalities like trisomy 8, isochromosome 17q

  • Additional clonal chromosomal abnormalities (like Ph chromosome, trisomy 8, isochromosome 17q) are an additional criterion for the diagnosis of accelerated phase of chronic myeloid leukemia according to WHO 2017 criteria.

choices.text: It is detected in blood during sepsis

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding neutrophil extracellular trapping (NET) except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mitochondrial DNA is seen

  • Mitochondrial DNA is not seen in neutrophil extracellular traps (NET).
  • Neutrophilic extracellular traps (NET) are a network of neutrophil nuclear chromatin/DNA. The death of neutrophils is caused by the loss of nuclei. They assemble antimicrobial peptides and enzymes to combat bacteria and fungi (not viruses). During sepsis, they are detected in the blood.
  • They are produced by neutrophils in response to:
    • Infectious pathogens: mainly bacteria and fungi
    • Inflammatory mediators: chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency room with renal colic. His vital signs are normal and a urinalysis shows microscopic haematuria. A radiograph reveals a 1.5 cm stone in pelvis. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Extracorporeal lithotripsy

  • The most appropriate treatment for this patient is extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy given the size of his renal stone (1.5 cm).
  • This procedure is completely non-invasive and uses a device that delivers convergent shockwave energy to the stone under fluoroscopic guidance.
  • Many patients with renal stones smaller than 0.5 cm can be managed with hydration and analgesics until the stone passes spontaneously.
  • α-Adrenergic blockers, which are usually used in the treatment of men with bladder outlet obstruction, have recently been shown to potentiate the likelihood of stone expulsion for small stones.
  • Percutaneous nephrolithotomy is preferred for large (> 2cm stones), stones in lower calyx or hard stones not amenable to ESWL.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the modified Duke's criteria?
questions.solution:

questions.text: During a physical examination, lung function tests are performed. The results show that the sum of tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, and expiratory reserve volume in the lungs is significantly reduced. What is the term used to describe the reduced sum of these lung volumes in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vital capacity

  • The vital capacity (VC) can be defined as the maximal volume of air expired from maximal inspiratory level and will be equal to the sum of tidal volume (TV), inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) and expiratory reserve volume (ERV).
  • The tidal volume (TV) can be defined as the volume of air inspired (or expired) during each normal breath
  • The additional volume of air that can be inspired above the tidal respiration is termed as inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)
  • The additional volume of air that can be expired more than normal expiration is termed as expiratory reserve volume (ERV)
  • Lung volumes and capacity measurements. Lung volumes recorded by a spirometer. Lung capacities are determined from volume recordings.

Option B. The suprascapular nerve innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles.

Option D. The subscapular nerves supply the teres major and subscapularis muscles.

questions.text: What is the maximum duration for TRALI to manifest following a blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 6 hours

  • The maximum duration for TRALI (transfusion-related acute lung injury) to occur after blood transfusion is 6 hours.
  • TRALI is characterized as sudden onset respiratory failure that occurs during or shortly after a blood transfusion.
  • The pathogenesis is based on a two-hit hypothesis:
    • Priming event: increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the lung microvasculature
    • Second knock: the factor (most commonly MHC class I antigens) present in the transfused blood product stimulates the primed neutrophils
  • Pathogenesis of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI):
    1. Dysregulation of Inflammatory Process: This indicates an imbalance or dysregulation in the normal inflammatory response.
    2. Leukocyte Antigen (Ag) Recipient: Refers to the recipient's leukocytes, which play a role in the immune response.
    3. Blood AB Donor: Indicates the presence of antibodies (AB) in the donated blood.
    4. First Hit: Represents an initial insult or trigger such as trauma, sepsis, or neutrophil activation that can activate the immune system.
    5. Endothelial Permeability: Describes the increased permeability of endothelial cells lining blood vessels.
    6. Second Hit: Refers to a secondary insult, which in this case is the transfusion of blood components.
    7. Transfusion Blood Components: Represents the infusion of blood products, including lysophosphatidylcholine (Lyso PC).
    8. Endothelial Activation: Activation of endothelial cells leading to cytokine release, which is the release of signalling molecules involved in immune responses.
    9. Common Pathway: Illustrates that both the first hit and the second hit converge to activate a common pathway.
    10. Alveolar Capillary Pulmonary Damage: Indicates the injury and damage occurring in the alveolar-capillary membrane in the lungs.
    11. Acute Respiratory Failure: Refers to the development of sudden respiratory distress and failure.
       
  • TRALI vs TACO:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male recently underwent surgery to remove a parathyroid gland due to hyperparathyroidism. The surgeon informed the patient that one or more of the parathyroid glands may be transferred to another location during the surgery. The parathyroid is commonly transferred to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Left brachioradialis

  • The most common site for relocation of the parathyroid gland(s) is in the forearm muscle (Brachioradialis) of non-dominant side.
  • The transferred gland(s) will continue to function and produce parathyroid hormone as normal in their new location, helping to regulate calcium levels in the body.
  • This also facilitates easy removal if there is disease recurrence after surgery.
  • A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted. This is a type of heterotopic transplant.

choices.text: Obtain a detailed history
Further clinical examination

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a 48-hour history of itching and oozing from a lesion behind her ear. She states that the symptoms began a day after she started wearing a new pair of gold earrings. On physical examination, the area behind her earlobe reveals an erythematous, weepy patch that corresponds to where the earring's backing would rest. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Patch test

  • When a person is exposed to an allergen, such as nickel or other metals often found in jewelry, the immune system can react, leading to an allergic skin response like dermatitis.
  • Common symptoms can include redness, itching, and even blisters.
  • Gold can also sometimes be the cause of such reactions, especially if the gold is not pure and has other metal alloys mixed with it.
  • Patch test is a method used to diagnose allergens responsible for causing contact dermatitis.
  • In this method, small patches soaked with potential allergens are applied to the skin for 48 hours.
  • After this time, the skin is examined for any reaction.
  • If there's a reaction, it indicates that the person is allergic to that specific substance.

Patch test depicted in the above image

  • History: It's always crucial to take a patient's history into account as it provides context and can give clues to the cause of an issue. In this case, the history suggests a possible allergic reaction to the gold earrings, but history alone cannot confirm a diagnosis.
  • Clinical examination: A clinical examination can identify signs and symptoms of dermatitis but cannot specifically identify its cause.
  • RAST (Radioallergosorbent test) is a blood test that's used to detect specific IgE antibodies in response to potential allergens. However, it's more commonly used for systemic allergies (like food or pollen) rather than contact allergies like what might be seen with metal jewelry.

questions.text: What is the observational unit in ecological investigations?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Population

  • In ecological studies, the unit of observation is the population or community, which refers to a group of individuals or entities living in the same geographic area or sharing a common characteristic.
  • Ecological studies are observational studies that investigate the relationship between exposure and disease at a population level rather than an individual level.
  • Therefore, the data collected and analyzed in ecological studies are not at the individual level, but at the group or population level.

Added advantage is that it can be taken orally
